Bruce,

What you've done looks good from the JUnit side at first glance.  I=

wonder if the ant team is maintaining their own copy of part of the
JUnit =
infrastructure, which handles assumptions in a different way?
It might be w=
orth asking the ant team.  Good luck,

   David Saff

On Wed, Jul 14, 2010 =
at 9:00 PM, Bruce <brewsterw@...> wrote:
> Hi,
> I want to use the As=
sume class to dynamically turn off some tests. There are tests I want run w=
hen we run full regression but not at other times. I have implemented an as=
sume line that I thought would ignore the test as follows
> String buildTyp=
e =3D System.getenv(BUILD_TYPE);
> Assume.assumeNotNull(buildType);
> Assum=
e.assumeTrue(buildType.equals(DAILY_BUILD));
>
> The test runs and exits wh=
en it reaches the assumeNotNull as I expected. However when all my tests fi=
nish I get an error in the junit report
> build.xml:1100: JunitTests failed=
. Check "C:\DEV\junitreport
>
> Inside of the report I have the following
>=

> =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0 =A0<error message=3D"got: <[null]>, expected: each not n=
ull" type=3D"org.junit.internal.AssumptionViolatedException"> =A0 =A0 =A0 =
=A0at com.MyCode.InclusionFileProcessTest.testLoadLargeListbyId(InclusionFi=
leProcessTest.java:352)
> </error>
>
> To me ignoring the test would mean j=
ust that, nothing happens. Am I doing something wrong? I have recently upgr=
aded from junit 3.x to 4.x have I missed something in the upgrade?
>
